div.p:
Letter not found. The text given here is from 'Kinney's Eucalypts', Los Angeles herald, 11 October 1896, p. 5 (B96.09.03). The letter is introduced with the following text: ‘The following letter addressed to Mr. Abbot Kinney from Baron Ferd. von Mueller, the recognized authority on the eucalyptus, is the most valuable appreciation of Mr. Kinney’s lately published work’ (i.e. Kinney (1895)). MELBOURNE. Australia, Sept. 29 [1896]
editorial addition. While Kinney’s book bears the imprint date of 1895, and it is mentioned as ‘about to be published’ in Los Angeles herald, 6 October 1895, p. 24, publication may have been delayed, because an article in Pacific rural press, 18 July 1896, p. 1, refers to the work as ‘just published’. Delayed or not, unless we reject both of these reports we must conclude that M could not have received a copy of the book and written this letter on 29 September in any other year than 1896. If, however, the letter was written in 1896, the 29 September date must be in error, since even on the fastest steamers plying the route, no letter posted in Australia on 29 September could have arrived in California in time to be published on 11 October.

Let me express my best thanks, dear Mr. Kinney, for sending me your admirable publication of the Eucalyptus.
In his Foreword, Kinney wrote
The botanical works covering this genus are inaccessible to the public on account of their great cost. There are only three copies of the Eucalyptographia and two of Bentham's books in this State, as far as I know. The importance of this genus as producers of kino, oils, timber and fuel, for ornament and the reclamation of waste places and for the probable sanitary effects of several of the species together with the rapidity of growth of nearly all and the remarkable adaptability to the major portion of California makes a means of identification a want that should be supplied.
Baron Ferdinand Von Mueller has, in the broad spirit of a true scientific man, given me the use of his great work on this genus, even to copying the plates.
I have taken advantage of the courtesy of this distinguished man but the cost of using the plates would have defeated the main object I had in view, which is to make the knowledge of the Eucalyptus accessible to the largest possible number of enquirers.
The Foreword also indicated that the 'condensed botanic description of all the species of Eucalyptus described by Baron Von Mueller' was 'taken from his great work' (i.e. Eucalyptographia; see B79.13.10, B80.13.14, B82.13.17, B83.13.07 and B84.11.02). It is an important contribution toward the knowledge of the species which came under your observations in California.
It is of great interest to learn how various species in different countries succeed, as that also helps to make the best choice for subsequent sendings.

If you can mention, from the “second census” of Australian plants,
B89.13.12. which species are not yet in culture with you, I would make strenuous effort to supply the seeds.
If I can in any other manner promote your study of this group of plants, it will be done with the utmost of pleasure.
It is remarkable that in the wide range of your literary versatility, you should have been led also to the eucalyptus.
